Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from numerous fragments withadded plaster) of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice with root of handle; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; lotus flower and rosette chain in added white outline and added red centres above red and white billet pattern between white bands; below, red and white rosettes above maeander pattern running left; below that, three white bands and red and white tongues; exterior: maeander and square pattern between brown bands at rim; below, painted decoration consisting of animal frieze (from left, horn and foreleg of bull, to right; lion, to left; hindquarters of feline, to right); pendant triangle and elaborate rosettes as filling ornament; in handle zone, broken maeander pattern between pairs of lines, above double guilloche; on left, at root of handle tongue pattern; four dark brown bands on bowl.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis), Context Φ3, Φ4 or Φ7.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as a heavy chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice-kraters. Chalices in this group display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1). The sherd is also published in Bergeron, M. forthcoming, ‘Pots and People: Greek trade and votive rituals at Naukratis’, in L. Hulin (ed.), Heracleion in Context: The Maritime Economy of the Egyptian Late Period, Oxford.
